title: RL32388
content: This report, General Management Laws: Major Themes and Management Policy Options, is a companion to CRS Report RL30795, General Management Laws: A Compendium. The main objectives are to identify and describe major general management laws, assist Congress in overseeing executive branch management, and help in considering potential changes to management laws and legislation. The quality and implementation of these laws are crucial for maintaining executive branch accountability and influencing federal agency effectiveness in policy formulation. The companion report focuses on major themes and management policy options for Congress related to general management laws for the executive branch. It includes over 90 entries organized into seven functional categories, reflecting the status of these laws at the end of the first session of the 108th Congress. The curr_chunk discusses general management laws for the executive branch, organized into seven functional categories. These categories include Information and Regulatory Management, Strategic Planning, Financial Management, Organization, Procurement, Intergovernmental Relations, and Human Resources Management. The focus is on specific laws within each category, with a particular emphasis on civil service laws codified in Title 5 of the United States Code. The curr_chunk provides a detailed overview of how specific civil service laws are presented in the compendium, including a brief history, major provisions, key developments, and source readings. It also discusses the roles of Congress and the President in managing the executive branch, compares management in public and private sectors, and analyzes major themes in general management laws. The debate over whether the President or Congress has more power in managing the executive branch is highlighted.
